Let's analyze the `starwars` data:

```{r}
starwars <- read_csv(restaurant <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/DOHMH_NYC_Restaurant_Inspection.csv'))
```
ggplot(restaurant) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = SCORE, y = GRADE, fill = GRADE) ) +
  facet_grid( `CRITICAL FLAG` ~ . )
  
ggplot(restaurant) +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = SCORE), binwidth = 1 ) +
  facet_grid( `CRITICAL FLAG` ~ GRADE )
  
ggplot(restaurant) +
  geom_bar(aes(x = `CRITICAL FLAG`,
               y = after_stat(prop), group = 1)) +
  facet_grid( GRADE ~ BORO )

## Variable Description for `starwars` data.frame

The following describes the variables in the `starwars` data.frame.


- `films`
List of films the character appeared in

- `name`
Name of the character

- `species`
Name of species

- `height`
Height (cm)

- `mass`
Weight (kg)

- `hair_color`, `skin_color`, `eye_color`
Hair, skin, and eye colors

- `birth_year`
Year born (BBY = Before Battle of Yavin)

- `sex`
The biological sex of the character, namely male, female, hermaphroditic, or none (as in the case for Droids).

- `gender`
The gender role or gender identity of the character as determined by their personality or the way they were programmed (as in the case for Droids).

- `homeworld`
Name of homeworld


## Human vs. Droid

```{r}
ggplot(data = 
         starwars %>% 
         filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid"))) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = species, y = mass, 
                   fill = species),
               show.legend = FALSE)

```
